entries.text: Will Braswell (Will_the_Chill) is running a fund-raiser for the RPerl project. As I understand, it is a very optimized Perl 5 compiler implementing part of the language. What Will calls the low magic commands. It was also discussed on Reddit.
entries.title: Perl 5 Optimizing Compiler, Part 10: Kickstarter & Performance Benchmarks

entries.text: This is the announcement of Peteris Krumins himself. AFAIK the Perl Weekly discount code is still valid. (It is PERLWEEKLY)
entries.title: Perl One-Liners has been published by No Starch Press

entries.text: This is a Perl distribution for Linux. The first release of the new series of releases that come with C libraries as well. This version comes with XML::LibXML (and thus libxml2). Just download, unzip and you can use it. List of extra CPAN modules on the site of DWIM Perl for Linux
entries.title: DWIM Perl for Linux 5.18.1

entries.text: Look, new toys! David Golden worked on quite a few CPAN modules lately without blogging about them. Now he collected the list: Class::Tiny, Path::Tiny, MooseX::Role::MongoDB,CPAN::Common::Index just to mention some of them.
entries.title: The xdg channel - Thanksgiving missive

entries.text: Is Perl a secret weapon in Banks? Do any of them admit it? Can you find people who work at some of the largest money-making institutions that heavily rely on Perl. Dave Cross reposted a request for some 'proof that Perl is indeed used in the finance industry' and he got quite some. Now how can you turn this into money?
entries.title: Perl in Banks

entries.text: Great story by Ovid about the BBC, and why reducing the test run-time can increase the productivity of your team.
entries.title: Why Are Fast Tests Important?

entries.text: The CPAN adoption list ranks modules how important it would be for you to step-up and volunteer to maintain them. It takes into account several factors, and starting from now, it also includes the test reports collected by the CPAN Testers.
entries.title: Including CPAN Testers results in the adoption list

entries.text: In the last few weeks there seem to be a lot of action around Perl::Critic people creating new policies. This time Jonas Nielsen has written a policy for checking for the use of Params::Validate.
entries.title: New Perl::Critic policy in the pipeline: RequireParamsValidate

entries.text: Ron Savage pointed out that there was a discussion on Slashdot about a bus service in Helsinki, Finland that broadcasts the data for the tram stop display system. Oona Räisänen took the lead and reverse engineered the data. Using some Perl code.
entries.title: Decoding radio-controlled bus stop displays

entries.text: Plotly offers a graphing library for scientific Perl/PDL. I don't see a dead-line, but they plan to announce the winner on 29 December 2013, so you better send your graphs in the next 2-3 weeks.
entries.title: New Perl Graphing library and competition from Plot.ly
